questionList.questionText: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the office due to enuresis.  Although she has been toilet-trained since age 3, she has been wetting the bed most nights for the past 6 months.  The patient has had no episodes of daytime incontinence.  She goes to sleep easily at night in her own room.  Her mother reports that she moves around a lot when sleeping and snores loudly.  The patient is often tired after coming home from school and naps for 2 hours most afternoons.  On examination, tympanic membranes are clear.  The nasal septum is straight, and there is no rhinorrhea; there is tonsillar hypertrophy.  There is no cervical adenopathy.  The lungs are clear to auscultation and heart sounds are normal.  Urinalysis is unremarkable.  The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questionList.explanationText:
Pediatric obstructive sleep apnea

Pathophysiology

  • Adenotonsillar hypertrophy

Clinical manifestations

  • Night symptoms
    • Loud snoring, pauses in breathing, gasping
    • Enuresis, parasomnias (eg, sleepwalking, sleep terrors)
  • Day symptoms
    • Inappropriate naps or falling asleep during school
    • Irritability, inattention, learning problems, behavioral problems
    • Mouth breathing, nasal speech

Complications

  • Poor growth (ie, failure to thrive)
  • Poor school performance
  • Cardiopulmonary (eg, hypertension, structural heart changes)

Management

  • Tonsillectomy & adenoidectomy

This child who was toilet-trained and now wets the bed has secondary enuresis.  In the context of disturbed sleep with loud snoring, daytime fatigue, and tonsillar hypertrophy, this is likely related to obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

As in adults, OSA in children is a sleep disorder in which episodic upper airway obstruction occurs.  In adults, the obstruction is usually caused by obesity, whereas in young children, it is often due to adenotonsillar hypertrophy.  The obstruction results in difficulty breathing and disrupted sleep (eg, snoring, restless sleep, apnea).  Daytime symptoms in children may include sleepiness (as in this patient) or manifest as inattention, learning difficulties, and behavioral problems.  In addition, night symptoms in children may also include parasomnias and enuresis.  The mechanism of enuresis is unclear, but it may be related to the elevated levels of B-type natriuretic peptide seen with OSA, possibly due to intermittent obstruction causing increased cardiac volume and pressure.

Untreated OSA in children, as in adults, can result in serious cardiovascular complications likely related to disruption of autonomic neural control due to sympathetic activation during periods of hypoxia.  Cardiovascular consequences can include systemic hypertension, tachycardia, structural heart changes (eg, right or left ventricular hypertrophy), and pulmonary hypertension, although the latter is more commonly associated with adult than pediatric OSA.

(Choice A)  Severe adenotonsillar hypertrophy can lead to dysphagia, but does not typically result in aspiration.

(Choice B)  Multiple sclerosis, which can present with internuclear ophthalmoplegia, can result in secondary enuresis or other urinary difficulties (eg, due to bladder dysfunction).  However, this patient's tonsillar hypertrophy, snoring, and daytime fatigue make OSA much more likely.

(Choice C)  Ketoacidosis is a common complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus.  Polyuria, a common presenting symptom of diabetes mellitus, can cause secondary enuresis in children.  However, diabetes mellitus would not cause adenotonsillar hypertrophy or snoring, and urinalysis would likely show glucosuria.

(Choice D)  Recurrent urinary tract infections can cause secondary enuresis and are a risk factor for pyelonephritis.  However, patients typically also have daytime symptoms, and urinalysis would likely show leukocyte esterase, nitrites, pyuria, and/or bacteriuria.

Educational objective:
Obstructive sleep apnea in children can present with secondary enuresis.  Severe cases can result in cardiovascular complications.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Obstructive sleep apnea

questionList.questionText: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to fever for the past 5 days.  He has also had a cough productive of yellow-green mucus.  The patient had pneumonia a year ago that required hospitalization for hypoxia.  Currently, he takes no daily medications other than acetaminophen as needed for fever.  The patient has received all of his vaccinations except for an annual influenza vaccine.  His family is originally from Peru, but he was born in the United States and has not traveled outside of the country.  Temperature is 38.9 C (102 F), blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 20/min.  Pulse oximetry is 99% on room air.  His weight is at the 75th percentile, and review of his medical records reveals that he is growing well.  Physical examination reveals a young child with moist mucous membranes, rales and decreased breath sounds over the left lower lung, and comfortable work of breathing.  Chest x-ray demonstrates an opacity over the lower left lung with minimal layering of fluid on lateral decubitus film.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient presents with a history and radiographic findings suggestive of pneumonia and a parapneumonic pleural effusion.  Pleural inflammation secondary to bacterial pneumonia can lead to leakage of exudative fluid into the pleural space.  Patients may present with symptoms of bacterial pneumonia (eg, fever, cough), and examination usually reveals focal rales, decreased or absent breath sounds, or dullness to percussion over the affected area.  Children with small effusions may be breathing comfortably with normal vital signs, although those with moderate to large effusions typically exhibit signs of respiratory distress (eg, grunting, nasal flaring, subcostal retractions), tachypnea, and hypoxia.

Although the diagnosis can be suspected from history and physical examination, chest x-ray confirms the presence of pleural fluid (eg, obscuring of costophrenic angle, layering fluid on lateral decubitus film).  For small pleural effusions in patients without respiratory distress, such as this patient, management includes oral antibiotics and close follow-up on an outpatient basis.

(Choice A)  Chest physiotherapy can aid in the mobilization of secretions in patients with cystic fibrosis or bronchiectasis.  It is not recommended in the treatment of pneumonia or pleural effusions as it is not shown to shorten hospital stay and may prolong cough.

(Choices B and C)  In patients with moderate or large effusions, ultrasonography and drainage (eg, chest tube, video-assisted thorascopic surgery [VATS]) are indicated.  CT scan is typically only performed to assess for rare complications (eg, pulmonary necrosis, abscess).

(Choice E)  Diuretics can be used to decrease effusions in the presence of transudative pleural effusions (eg, secondary to cardiac failure or cirrhosis).  Diuretics are not indicated in the treatment of parapneumonic effusions.

(Choice F)  Pleural effusions from Mycobacterium tuberculosis are exudative and result from a delayed hypersensitivity reaction.  The absence of travel, upper lobe parenchymal disease, and weight loss makes tuberculosis much less likely than a primary bacterial pneumonia complicated by parapneumonic effusion.

Educational objective:
Parapneumonic effusions occur after bacterial pneumonias lead to pleural inflammation and exudation of fluid into the pleural space.  Small effusions in children without respiratory distress can be managed with oral antibiotics and close outpatient follow-up.  Moderate or large effusions require drainage.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Community acquired pneumonia

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Current evidence for the management of paediatric parapneumonic effusions.
Pleural effusions.

questionList.questionText: A 12-year-old previously healthy girl is evaluated 48 hours after being admitted to the hospital for pneumonia.  She initially was brought to the emergency department due to worsening cough, shortness of breath, and fever at home for 3 days.  Chest x-ray on admission revealed a right lower lobe infiltrate, and intravenous ampicillin was started immediately.  A sputum culture is growing Streptococcus pneumoniae sensitive to ampicillin and ceftriaxone.  Blood cultures have no growth.  Current temperature is 39.4 C (102.9 F), blood pressure is 104/82 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 28/min.  On examination, heart sounds are normal.  Dullness to percussion and diminished breath sounds are heard at the right lung base.  The left lung is clear to auscultation.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Most children with uncomplicated community-acquired pneumonia typically improve within 48-72 hours of appropriate antibiotic therapy.  This patient with right lower lobe pneumonia and a persistent fever despite 48 hours of appropriate antibiotics requires further evaluation to assess for a complication such as parapneumonic effusion, abscess, or necrotizing pneumonia.  Therefore, the best next step in management is repeat chest x-ray to evaluate for these pneumonia-related complications.

This patient with dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds on examination likely has a parapneumonic effusion, in which infection or infection-related inflammation spreads to the pleural space.  Parapneumonic effusion can present with symptoms directly resulting from the effusion (eg, cough, pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea), or with signs and symptoms of pneumonia unresponsive to treatment, as in this patient.  Chest x-ray and/or ultrasound is performed to evaluate the effusion size and other characteristics (eg, free-flowing vs loculated).  Drainage is indicated for moderate or large effusions or if the patient is experiencing respiratory distress (this differs from the adult population, in which the need for drainage is determined mostly by fluid analysis).

(Choice A)  Azithromycin is a preferred treatment for atypical pneumonia organisms (eg, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Legionella pneumophila), which are not covered by beta-lactam antibiotics.  However, this patient is already on appropriate antibiotic coverage for culture-proven Streptococcus pneumoniae; the persistent fever and evidence of pleural effusion suggest extension of the infection into the pleural space, where there is poor antibiotic penetration.

(Choice B)  A procalcitonin level may help differentiate bacterial and viral pneumonia and guide the need for antibiotics.  This patient has a known bacterial infection with appropriate antibiotic coverage, and obtaining a procalcitonin level would not help guide management.

(Choice C)  Quantitative immunoglobulin levels are measured in patients with recurrent pneumonias or other infections to evaluate for possible immunodeficiency.  This patient has no history of recurrent infections; therefore, immunodeficiency evaluation is not indicated.

(Choice E)  Sputum cultures can help guide antibiotic selection when treating pneumonia.  This patient already has a culture growing Streptococcus pneumoniae; therefore, repeat sputum culture is unlikely to give additional information that would change the antibiotic choice.

Educational objective:
Children with pneumonia on appropriate antimicrobial therapy who have no improvement after 48-72 hours require evaluation with chest x-ray to assess for complications (eg, parapneumonic effusion).  Drainage is indicated for moderate or large effusions or those causing respiratory distress.

questionList.title: Parapneumonic effusion & Empyema

questionList.questionText: A 36-year-old man from California who had been skiing at a Colorado ski resort for 3 days developed cough, shortness of breath, headache, and dizziness.  The patient has no previous medical problems and takes no medication.  He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  Temperature is 38.3 C (100.9 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 102/min.  Oxygen saturation is 86% on room air.  Examination shows cyanosis, dry mucous membranes, normal jugular venous pressure, and bilateral lung crackles.  Heart sounds are normal.  There is no peripheral edema.  Neurologic examination shows no focal findings.  Leukocytes are 13,000/mm3 with 75% neutrophils.  The patient is given antibiotics and high-flow oxygen as well as strict bed rest.  Six hours later his symptoms markedly improve with a decrease in oxygen requirements.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Characteristics of high-altitude pulmonary edema versus multifocal pneumonia

High-altitude pulmonary edema

Multifocal pneumonia

  • Recent arrival at high altitude (<1 week)
  • Absent or mild leukocytosis
  • Procalcitonin normal
  • Marked early improvement with O2
  • Persistent stay at high altitude
  • Leukocytes >15,000 mm3 with bands
  • Procalcitonin elevated
  • Minimal early improvement with O2

This patient with shortness of breath, headache, and dizziness within several days of arriving at high elevation (ie, >2500 m [~8000 ft]) likely has high-altitude illness.  His cough, greater-than-expected hypoxemia, and bilateral lung crackles suggest high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE), a potential complication of high-altitude illness.

In response to the low partial pressure of inspired oxygen (PiO2) at high altitude, the lungs undergo hypoxic vasoconstriction to optimize alveolar-capillary gas exchange.  Some individuals have a genetic predisposition to developing unevenly distributed hypoxic vasoconstriction, which exposes the pulmonary capillaries in relatively less vasoconstricted areas to high perfusion pressure.  The regional elevations in perfusion pressure disrupt the alveolar-capillary membrane and lead to patchy, bilateral pulmonary edema (noncardiogenic pulmonary edema).

The differentiation of HAPE from bacterial pneumonia (Choice A) can be challenging as both conditions can cause fever, leukocytosis, hypoxemia, and bilateral lung crackles.

  • Recent ascent to high altitude suggests HAPE; conversely, an extended stay at high altitude prior to symptom onset rules out HAPE as it almost never occurs after >1 week at the same altitude.

  • Mild leukocytosis is common with HAPE, but leukocytes >15,000/mm3 or the presence of bands suggests bacterial pneumonia.

  • Rapid improvement of hypoxemia with supplemental oxygen is highly suggestive of HAPE.  Although hypoxemia due to multifocal pneumonia does not improve quickly with supplemental oxygen (due to widespread intrapulmonary shunting), supplemental oxygen alleviates the hypoxic vasoconstriction in HAPE to reduce alveolar-capillary perfusion pressure and rapidly improve the edema and hypoxemia.

(Choice B)  Cardiogenic pulmonary edema involves the transmission of elevated left atrial pressure back to the pulmonary veins and capillaries, most commonly due to left ventricular dysfunction (ie, decompensated heart failure).  Dry mucous membranes and the absence of jugular venous distension rule out volume overload and cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

(Choice D)  Although tachycardia and hypoxemia are typical of acute pulmonary thromboembolism, clear lungs would also be expected, and marked improvement within hours with antibiotics and oxygen therapy but not anticoagulation would be unusual.

(Choice E)  Although viral pneumonia can rarely present as alveolar consolidation with bilateral lung crackles, interstitial inflammation without alveolar consolidation (or lung crackles) is more typical.  Viral pneumonia can sometimes cause significant hypoxemia, but, as with bacterial pneumonia, the hypoxemia is unlikely to improve within several hours.

Educational objective:
High-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE) typically presents with shortness of breath, cough, hypoxemia, and bilateral lung crackles.  Characteristics that favor HAPE over multifocal pneumonia include recent ascent to high altitude, the absence of leukocytes >15,000/mm3, and rapid improvement with supplemental oxygen.

questionList.title: High altitude illness

questionList.questionText: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother due to noisy breathing.  Approximately 6 months ago, his older brother asked to be moved to a different room because the patient's noisy breathing was keeping him up at night; his mother reports that it sounds like he gasps for air while sleeping.  During the day, the patient breathes through his mouth and eats and drinks without gagging or choking.  He is able to keep up with his peers during outdoor play.  The patient takes no medications and is up to date with vaccinations.  He lives with his mother, father, older brother, and the family cat.  No one in the household smokes.  Height is at the 40th percentile and weight is at the 25th percentile.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Pediatric obstructive sleep apnea

Pathophysiology

  • Adenotonsillar hypertrophy

Clinical manifestations

  • Night symptoms
    • Loud snoring, pauses in breathing, gasping
    • Enuresis, parasomnias (eg, sleepwalking, sleep terrors)
  • Day symptoms
    • Inappropriate naps or falling asleep during school
    • Irritability, inattention, learning problems, behavioral problems
    • Mouth breathing, nasal speech

Complications

  • Poor growth (ie, failure to thrive)
  • Poor school performance
  • Cardiopulmonary (eg, hypertension, structural heart changes)

Management

  • Tonsillectomy & adenoidectomy

This child with loud snoring (eg, noisy breathing at night) and gasping for air during sleep likely has obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

As in adults, pediatric OSA is a sleep disorder in which there is episodic upper airway obstruction, resulting in difficulty breathing and disrupted sleep.  This often manifests as restless sleep, loud snoring, periods of apnea, and gasping for air.  In addition, night symptoms in children may also include enuresis and parasomnias.  In contrast to adults, children with OSA may not demonstrate daytime sleepiness.  Daytime symptoms in children may manifest as inattention, learning difficulties, and behavioral problems.

In adults, OSA is often associated with obesity.  Management includes weight loss and continuous positive airway pressure.  In contrast, OSA in young children is often due to adenotonsillar hypertrophy and may, in fact, result in failure to thrive (eg, low percentile for weight).  This patient's open-mouth breathing during the day suggests significant nasal airway obstruction by adenoid hypertrophy.  First-line management for pediatric OSA is tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy.

Both pediatric and adult OSA can result in significant cardiovascular complications (eg, hypertension, structural heart changes).

(Choice A)  Allergic rhinitis can present with open-mouth breathing due to nasal obstruction.  However, patients also typically have a runny nose, sneezing, and itchy eyes.

(Choice B)  Asthma can present with noisy breathing, and attacks commonly occur at night.  However, if asthma attacks were severe enough to be audible, the patient would wake up fully.  In addition, the patient would likely have difficulty breathing during vigorous daytime play.

(Choice C)  Although bilateral choanal atresia (ie, congenital blockage of the nasal cavity) presents with noisy breathing, it occurs in neonates.  Unilateral choanal atresia becomes symptomatic in childhood but presents with chronic nasal discharge rather than difficulty breathing.

(Choice D)  Laryngomalacia is characterized by floppy supraglottic structures that collapse during inspiration due to laryngeal hypotonia (possibly from delayed maturation).  It causes inspiratory stridor that worsens in the supine position.  However, it presents in infancy and typically resolves by age 18 months.

(Choice F)  Vascular rings are congenital malformations of the great vessels that encircle and compress the trachea and/or esophagus.  Respiratory symptoms classically include biphasic stridor that improves with neck extension.  Symptoms would be worse with activity rather than during sleep.

Educational objective:
Nighttime snoring and gasping for air is suspicious for obstructive sleep apnea, which is commonly caused by adenotonsillar hypertrophy in children.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Obstructive sleep apnea

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Managing the child with persistent sleep apnea.
Pediatric obstructive sleep apnea.

questionList.questionText: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office with cough and blood-tinged sputum.  She developed malaise, nasal congestion, sore throat, and dry cough 10 days ago.  Most of her symptoms improved, but the cough persisted and became productive of yellowish sputum.  For the past 2 days, she has had several episodes of blood-tinged sputum.  The patient has no chest pain except the discomfort from coughing.  Her appetite is normal, and she has no weight loss.  She feels anxious as she has never had blood in the sputum before.  She is a nonsmoker, has no other medical problems, and denies international travel.  Her vaccinations are up to date.  The patient's temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 132/80 mm Hg, pulse is 82/min, and respirations are 18/min.  Pulse oximetry is 98% on room air.  Her BMI is 29 kg/m2, and the oropharynx is clear.  Scattered bilateral wheezes and crackles that clear with coughing are heard on chest auscultation.  Chest x-ray reveals clear lung fields.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Acute bronchitis

Etiology

  • Preceding respiratory illness (90% viral)

Clinical presentation

  • Cough for >5 days to 3 weeks (± purulent sputum)
  • Absent systemic findings (eg, fever, chills)
  • Wheezing or rhonchi, chest wall tenderness

Diagnosis & treatment

  • Clinical diagnosis, CXR only when pneumonia suspected
  • Symptomatic treatment (eg, NSAIDs &/or bronchodilators)
  • Antibiotics not recommended

CXR = chest x-ray; NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

This nonsmoking patient with symptoms of recent upper respiratory infection (URI) and persistent cough productive of yellow, blood-tinged sputum likely has acute bronchitis.

Cough lasting >5 days is characteristic of acute bronchitis, and a viral URI is the usual cause.  Sputum production occurs in roughly half of patients; the typical yellow/purulent sputum is due to epithelial sloughing and is not a sign of bacterial infection.  Small amounts of blood in the sputum can occur due to inflammation and epithelial damage.  Mild dyspnea and chest wall discomfort are common, and physical examination often shows wheezing as well as crackles that clear with cough, suggesting that secretions are easily mobilized (unlike in pneumonia).  Fever is not typical and, when present, should raise suspicion for bacterial pneumonia or influenza.

The illness is self-limiting (although cough and airway hypersensitivity may persist for weeks), and only symptomatic treatment (eg, nonprescription pain relievers) is indicated.  Antibiotics should generally be avoided as they provide no significant benefit (including in acute bronchitis due to Mycoplasma species) and are associated with adverse effects.

(Choices A and B)  Chest CT and flexible bronchoscopy can be useful in the diagnosis and treatment of recurrent or large-volume hemoptysis.  This patient with small-volume hemoptysis in the setting of a URI, unremarkable chest x-ray, and no risk factors for malignancy (eg, smoking) or bronchiectasis (eg, recurrent infection) requires no further investigation.

(Choice C)  Patients with chronic cough may be evaluated with pulmonary function testing if asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is suspected.  Cough due to acute bronchitis is usually self-limiting, and pulmonary function testing is not indicated.

(Choice D)  Sputum acid-fast stain is used to diagnose tuberculous infection in patients with chronic cough and constitutional symptoms such as weight loss or night sweats.  An unremarkable chest x-ray and absence of risk factors (eg, international travel) make tuberculosis unlikely.

(Choice E)  Sputum cytology can occasionally help in the diagnosis of lung cancer, but sensitivity is poor.  Lung cancer is very unlikely in this young patient with no smoking history.

(Choice F)  Most cases of acute bronchitis are viral, and sputum culture is not recommended unless pneumonia is suspected.  The absence of fever and consolidation on chest x-ray makes pneumonia very unlikely.

Educational objective:
Acute bronchitis is a common cause of cough that may be productive of purulent, blood-tinged sputum.  Upper respiratory viral infection is the typical etiology, and symptoms are usually self-limiting.  Symptomatic treatment and close clinical follow-up are the best management strategies.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Acute bronchitis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Hemoptysis: diagnosis and management.
Diagnosis and treatment of acute bronchitis.

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old, previously healthy man undergoes screening colonoscopy.  The patient had bowel preparation with laxatives and was NPO for 8 hours prior to the procedure.  The preanesthesia physical examination was normal.  Intravenous propofol is administered for procedural conscious sedation.  During the procedure, the patient is turned to supine from the left lateral position due to difficult colonic intubation.  Immediately after repositioning, he has a large, nonparticulate, yellow emesis.  Oropharyngeal suctioning is performed, and the patient's oxygen saturation transiently decreases.  After completion of the procedure, he reports a burning sensation in his throat, hoarseness, and mild dyspnea.  Lung auscultation reveals fine crackles on the right side.  Chest x-ray obtained several hours later shows mild infiltrate in the posterior segment of the right lower lobe.  Which of the following is the most likely outcome of this patient's pulmonary complication?
questionList.explanationText:
Aspiration: pneumonitis vs pneumonia

Chemical pneumonitis

Aspiration pneumonia

Cause

  • Inhalation of gastric acid leads to direct chemical injury of bronchial & alveolar epithelial cells
  • Inhalation of large inoculate of oropharyngeal or gastric microbes overwhelms host pulmonary defenses

Onset

  • Sudden: within min or hr
  • Indolent: a few days to weeks

Manifestations

  • Abrupt-onset dyspnea, cough, hypoxemia
  • Low-grade fever
  • Diffuse crackles/wheezes
  • Infiltrate in dependent portion of lung
  • Fever
  • Cough with putrid sputum
  • Infiltrate in dependent portion of lung

Management

  • Supportive care
  • Oropharyngeal suction if event is witnessed
  • Antibiotics (eg, ceftriaxone plus azithromycin) that target community-acquired pneumonia pathogens

This patient had an episode of emesis while under conscious sedation with propofol for screening colonoscopy.  Because sedatives and general anesthesia impair the cough reflex and glottal function, exposure to these medications increases the risk of aspirating oropharyngeal or gastric contents.  Aspiration of gastric contents (eg, during emesis) can lead to 2 distinct clinical syndromes:

  • Chemical pneumonitis:  Aspiration of gastric acid causes erosive damage to the bronchial and alveolar epithelium, leading to symptoms within a few minutes or hours of exposure.  Manifestations typically include dyspnea, cough, hypoxemia, and low-grade fever.  Chest x-ray usually reveals an infiltrate in a dependent portion of the lung (eg, posterior segment of the upper lobes).  Most cases of chemical pneumonitis resolve spontaneously within 36 hours with supportive treatment; no antibiotics are generally required.

  • Bacterial aspiration pneumonia:  Aspiration of large quantities of microorganisms from the stomach or oropharynx can overwhelm host defense mechanisms, leading to pneumonia several days after the event.  Manifestations typically include progressive fever, cough productive of putrid sputum, and an infiltrate in a dependent portion of the lung.  Because recent data shows aspiration pneumonia is primarily due to upper airway aerobic bacteria (rather than anaerobes), first-line treatment targets community-acquired pneumonia pathogens (eg, amoxicillin plus azithromycin); in contrast, patients with aspiration pneumonia who also have empyema or lung abscess should be treated with agents that cover anaerobes (eg, ampicillin-sulbactam).

(Choice A)  Most cases of chemical pneumonitis do not lead to bacterial pneumonia.  Therefore, antibiotics are generally withheld unless respiratory status deteriorates 24-72 hours after the event.

(Choice B)  Bronchiectasis is marked by a long-standing cough with mucopurulent sputum.  It is often seen after foreign body inhalation (eg, chicken bone, peanut), not chemical pneumonitis.  Other common causes of bronchiectasis include cigarette smoking, cystic fibrosis, immunocompromised states, and rheumatoid arthritis.

(Choice C)  Patients with long-standing, recurrent aspiration of gastric acid (eg, severe gastroesophageal reflux disease) are at increased risk for pulmonary fibrosis.  However, a single aspiration event is unlikely to significantly increase pulmonary fibrosis risk.

(Choice E)  Patients with severe smoke inhalation injury or those who have been intubated >7 days are at increased risk for tracheal stenosis.  A single aspiration event is unlikely to cause this condition.

Educational objective:
Sedatives and general anesthesia increase the risk for aspiration.  Aspiration of gastric contents can lead to either chemical pneumonitis or bacterial pneumonia.  Symptoms of chemical pneumonitis (eg, cough, dyspnea, hypoxemia) typically occur within a few minutes/hours of aspiration and resolve spontaneously within 36 hours.  In contrast, symptoms of bacterial pneumonia (eg, fever, cough with putrid sputum) arise after several days and require antibiotics for resolution.

questionList.title: Aspiration pneumonia

questionList.questionText: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother due to behavioral difficulties for the past 6 months.  The patient's teacher has reported that he blurts answers out of turn and sometimes naps during individual reading time.  The patient has been struggling to keep up in school and gets frustrated easily, often throwing his homework on the floor.  The mother says, "He has also been fighting with his sister a lot, which is not like him.  She'll say something about his grades being low or how he snores at night, and then he'll push her or say something mean.  I'm 3 months pregnant, and we just told the kids last month, so there have been a lot of changes recently."  Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 20/min.  BMI is at the 98th percentile for age.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  During the evaluation, the boy is easily distracted and frequently interrupts his mother.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Conditions mimicking attention deficit hyperactivity disorder*

Diagnosis

Historical clues

Initial evaluation

Learning disability

  • Symptoms predominantly in academic setting
  • Neuropsychological testing

Hearing impairment

  • Delayed speech
  • Audiology evaluation

Mental health conditions

(eg, anxiety, depression, ODD)

  • Excessive worrying (anxiety), pervasive sadness (depression), defiance (ODD)
  • Interview & standardized screening questionnaires

Obstructive sleep apnea

  • Snoring, daytime sleepiness
  • Obesity
  • Sleep study

Absence seizure

  • Discrete episodes unresponsive to stimuli
  • Automatisms
  • EEG

*Symptoms of hyperactivity (eg, inability to sit still, frequent interruptions) &/or inattention (eg, distractibility, difficulty following directions).

EEG = electroencephalogram; ODD = oppositional defiant disorder.

This patient has symptoms of hyperactivity/impulsivity (eg, blurting out answers) and inattention (eg, easy distractibility), findings often attributed to attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in children.  However, other medical conditions (eg, seizures, hearing impairment) can have symptoms that mimic ADHD.  An alternate diagnosis should be considered when certain historical clues are present, particularly in a patient with sudden or late onset (eg, adolescence) of symptoms (Choice E).  In this case, the patient's elevated BMI, snoring, and daytime sleepiness raise concern for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

OSA is characterized by intermittent airway obstruction, resulting in fragmented sleep.  Adenotonsillar hypertrophy is often the cause in young children, but obesity is a common risk factor in adolescents.  Frequent snoring is typical, and insufficient sleep often leads to napping at unexpected times (eg, during school).  In some children, presentation may be limited to behavioral problems and symptoms overlapping with ADHD because excessive sleepiness can cause patients to be irritable (eg, fighting with sister), easily frustrated (eg, throwing homework), and impulsive.

Findings concerning for OSA warrant evaluation with a sleep study before a diagnosis of ADHD can be made because treatment with positive airway pressure typically results in improvement of behavioral problems in those with confirmed OSA.  Presuming a diagnosis of ADHD without evaluation for OSA may expose patients to unnecessary pharmacotherapy (eg, methylphenidate) and its potential side effects (Choice C).

(Choice A)  Childhood depression may cause irritability and can be treated with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (eg, escitalopram).  However, this patient's snoring and elevated BMI make OSA a more likely cause of his behavioral symptoms.  Moreover, a confidential interview and standardized depression screening questionnaire are typically performed before prescribing medication for depression.

(Choices B and D)  Family therapy may help address sibling fighting and changing family dynamics (eg, new child), while parent management training can help caregivers extinguish problematic behaviors (eg, interrupting).  However, evaluation for OSA takes precedence in this patient because symptoms would likely continue despite these interventions if OSA is present and remains untreated.

Educational objective:
Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) can present in children with symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and should be considered when other key findings are present, including obesity, snoring, and daytime sleepiness.  Evaluation with a sleep study is required before a diagnosis of ADHD can be made because treatment of OSA (eg, positive airway pressure) can lead to resolution of behavioral symptoms.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: Reassurance that this is normal adolescent behavior

Clinical practice guideline for the diagnosis, evaluation, and treatment of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder in children and adolescents.

questionList.questionText: A 68-year-old woman comes to the office due to gradually worsening shortness of breath.  Over the past several months, the patient has experienced dyspnea on exertion that is now bothersome with activities such as light housework.  She also describes a morning cough that produces minimal white sputum.  The patient has had no chest pain or fever.  She smoked a half-pack of cigarettes daily from age 18 to 50.  Blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Oxygen saturation is 94% on room air.  On physical examination, the patient is breathing comfortably without using accessory muscles of respiration.  The trachea is not deviated, and jugular venous pressure is normal.  Lung auscultation reveals bilateral vesicular breath sounds with occasional rhonchi that clear after the patient is asked to cough.  Heart sounds are normal.  Chest x-ray reveals no abnormalities.  On pulmonary function testing, FEV1 is 53% of predicted, and the FEV1/FVC ratio is 0.5.  These values are unchanged after administration of albuterol.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has a significant smoking history, chronic lower respiratory symptoms, and irreversible airflow obstruction (ie, FEV1/FVC ratio <0.7, unchanged after albuterol).  These findings are consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Although pulmonary function tests are crucial for COPD diagnosis, FEV1 is not a primary consideration for guiding therapy because it correlates poorly with treatment response.  Instead, selection of initial bronchodilator therapy for stable COPD depends on the following 2 dimensions: symptom severity, graded using a validated instrument (eg, COPD Assessment Test) that measures disease impact on daily life (higher severity: dyspnea during light housework); and exacerbation risk, assessed by the frequency and seriousness of acute exacerbations of COPD (higher risk: ≥1 hospitalizations or ≥2 outpatient exacerbations [ie, requiring use of oral corticosteroids at home] annually).

Patients are classified into groups (A, B, or E) based on the following factors:

  • For patients with more severe symptoms (ie, group B, such as this patient who has dyspnea with even light housework) or more frequent/serious exacerbations (ie, group E), preferred initial therapy includes a daily inhaled long-acting beta-2 agonist (LABA) (eg, formoterol) plus a long-acting muscarinic antagonist (LAMA) (eg, tiotropium).  Combination LABA plus LAMA therapy maximizes bronchodilation, stabilizes against bronchoconstriction, and reduces mucus hypersecretion.
  • For patients with low symptom severity and low exacerbation risk (ie, group A), an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (SABA) or short-acting muscarinic antagonist (SAMA) is used (eg, as needed).  Such patients tend to have early COPD with intermittent mild symptoms, unlike this patient who has persistent dyspnea interfering with daily activities (Choice C).

Patients should also be assessed for smoking cessation, pulmonary rehabilitation, supplemental oxygen, and vaccinations.

(Choice A)  The combination of an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) (eg, budesonide) and a LABA is preferred for initial treatment of asthma (reversible obstruction).  The ICS more effectively suppresses Th2 airway inflammation (asthma), whereas a LAMA more effectively suppresses goblet cell hyperplasia (COPD).  Large clinical trials have demonstrated superior outcomes with LABA-LAMA over ICS-LABA.  Use of an ICS also increases pneumonia risk in COPD due to topical pulmonary immunosuppression.

(Choice D)  A leukotriene antagonist (eg, montelukast) is used as adjunctive therapy for asthma, not COPD.  It would be especially helpful for aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (triad of asthma, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug sensitivity, and nasal polyposis).

(Choice E)  An oral corticosteroid is indicated for acute exacerbation of COPD (increased wheezing, sputum, and dyspnea) but not as initial therapy for stable disease.

Educational objective:
The combination of an inhaled long-acting beta-2 agonist and a long-acting muscarinic antagonist is the best initial therapy for stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with higher symptom severity (ie, dyspnea on light exertion) and/or exacerbation risk.

questionList.title: COPD

answerChoiceList.choice: Inhaled corticosteroid and long-acting beta agonist
Inhaled long-acting beta agonist and long-acting muscarinic antagonist
Inhaled short-acting beta agonist as needed

questionList.questionText: A 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of jaw swelling and pain.  Two weeks ago, the patient cracked a molar in his right lower jaw after biting on an unpopped popcorn kernel and underwent tooth extraction.  Yesterday, he developed a fever and the right side of his jaw began to swell.  The pain has been worsening in that area, and the patient is having trouble swallowing.  Temperature is 38.2 C (100.8 F), blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 22/min.  Oxygen saturation is 99% on room air.  On examination, the patient appears ill and is drooling.  His tongue appears elevated and is displaced posteriorly.  The floor of the patient's mouth feels firm.  His neck is erythematous, warm, and feels woody.  This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following immediate complications?
questionList.explanationText:
Ludwig angina is a rapidly progressive cellulitis of the submandibular and sublingual spaces.  Most cases arise from contiguous (rather than lymphatic) spread of polymicrobial dental infections in the mandibular molars.  This contiguous spread results in bilateral edema of the submandibular and sublingual spaces.  As the submandibular area becomes tender and indurated, the floor of the mouth becomes elevated and displaces the tongue posteriorly, which may lead to acute airway obstruction.  Additional clinical features of Ludwig angina include a neck that is often described as "woody" or "brawny" but has no associated lymphadenopathy.

As with other lesions that threaten the airway, patients with examination findings concerning for impending airway obstruction (eg, drooling, inability to lay flat, tripod positioning) should have their airway secured, regardless of current oxygen saturation.  This is because oxygen saturation is often maintained until very rapid decompensation (within minutes).  Therefore, these patients require continued assessment and, if needed, intervention to secure the airway (eg, nasotracheal intubation, awake tracheostomy).

(Choice A)  Infection within the retropharyngeal space can present with dysphagia, hoarseness, and shortness of breath; however, this is due to edema in the posterior pharyngeal wall rather than displacement of the tongue.  It is most likely to extend through the alar fascia into the "danger space", which can then progress into the posterior mediastinum and result in acute necrotizing mediastinitis.

(Choice C)  Carotid artery rupture occurs when the vasa vasorum supplying the carotid is injured; it is most often a complication of head and neck cancer (eg, tumor invasion, tissue removal) and is not typically associated with deep neck space infection.

(Choice D)  Infections originating in the maxillary space, not the mandibular space (as seen in this patient), can spread to the infratemporal space and orbit and progress to cavernous sinus thrombosis.

(Choice E)  Acute otitis media can spread throughout the temporal bone and cause facial nerve palsy due to inflammation of the nerve as it travels through the tympanic and mastoid portions of the temporal bone.  Submandibular space infections do not typically cause facial nerve palsy.

(Choice F)  Deep neck space infections are typically prevented from spread into the epidural space (eg, to form a spinal epidural abscess) by the vertebral column and posterior longitudinal ligament.

Educational objective:
Ludwig angina is a rapidly progressive cellulitis of the submandibular and sublingual spaces.  Airway obstruction can occur due to displacement of the tongue posteriorly.

questionList.questionText: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother after drowning.  They were at a pool party when another child told the mother that her son was under water and not moving.  She immediately pulled the boy out and administered 3 rescue breaths, and he started coughing up water.  On arrival, temperature is 36.1 C (97 F),  blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 26/min.  Oxygen saturation is 97% on room air.  The patient is awake, alert, and well appearing.  He is talkative and playful and asking to eat at a restaurant.  The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.  Neurologic examination is normal.  What is the appropriate disposition of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient who experienced nonfatal drowning is now alert and well appearing, with normal vital signs and a normal physical examination.  However, he is at risk for developing delayed pulmonary complications.

Aspiration of a large amount of fluid often occurs during drowning.  Even if the fluid is coughed out quickly (as this patient did) and normal ventilation is restored, the fluid may have already caused damage capable of resulting in delayed pulmonary complications.  This damage may include:

  • Direct tissue injury from chemicals or contaminants in the fluid, leading to inflammation

  • Washout of alveolar surfactant, leading to alveolar collapse

  • Disruption of the osmotic gradient of the alveolar-capillary membrane, leading to increased fluid permeability

Together, these insults can progressively impair oxygen exchange and cause atelectasis, decreased lung compliance, and noncardiogenic pulmonary edema.  Without treatment, these complications can rapidly progress to life-threatening acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Most asymptomatic patients who develop delayed pulmonary complications exhibit symptoms within the first 8 hours; therefore, they should be closely observed in the emergency department or another hospital unit (rather than discharged home) for at least that long (Choice D).  At the end of the prolonged observation period, chest x-ray should be repeated.  If it is normal and the patient remains asymptomatic with normal vital signs (including oxygen saturation), then the patient can be discharged.

(Choice B)  Arterial blood gases (ABGs) are often measured in drowning victims (even if asymptomatic) and sometimes demonstrate hypoxemia and metabolic acidosis.  However, even patients with normal ABGs require a prolonged (ie, ≥8 hr) observation period due to the risk of delayed pulmonary complications.

(Choice C)  In asymptomatic patients, early chest x-rays (eg, at initial evaluation) may be falsely reassuring because pulmonary complications can be delayed.  Instead, a chest x-ray should be obtained at the end of the prolonged (ie, ≥8 hr) observation period.

Educational objective:
Patients who are asymptomatic after nonfatal drowning should undergo prolonged (ie, ≥8 hr) observation due to the risk of delayed pulmonary complications.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Drowning

answerChoiceList.choice: Admit to the hospital for observation
Discharge home now if arterial blood gases are normal
Discharge home now if chest x-ray is normal
Discharge home now without additional workup

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Prevention and treatment of drowning.
Drowning.

questionList.questionText: A 75-year-old man is brought to the office due to 2 days of confusion and poor food consumption.  The patient has a history of Alzheimer dementia with behavioral symptoms, hypertension, and left lobe hepatic resection due to traumatic injury during a fall 2 years ago.  His medications include lisinopril, amlodipine, quetiapine, and donepezil.  He has never smoked cigarettes.  He lives at home with his wife and is usually ambulatory.  Temperature is 38.8 C (101.8 F), blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg, pulse is 106/min, and respirations are 18/min.  BMI is 24 kg/m2.  His height is 193 cm (6 ft 4 in).  The patient appears ill and is oriented to person only.  The neck is supple.  There is increased tactile fremitus and dullness to percussion at the right lung base.  Pulmonary auscultation reveals crackles over the lower right lung field.  The rest of the examination is normal.  Which of the following is the greatest risk factor for this patient's current condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Risk factors for community-acquired pneumonia

Impaired immunity

  • Age >65
  • HIV
  • Diabetes mellitus

Impaired pulmonary function

  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • Bronchiectasis/cystic fibrosis
  • Recent upper respiratory viral infection
  • Smoking

Increased microaspiration

  • Substance/alcohol use disorder
  • Seizure disorder or stroke
  • Esophageal dysmotility

Medications

  • Acid suppressants
  • Sedatives
  • Immunomodulatory agents

This patient's acute confusion, fever, tachycardia, and signs of right lower lung consolidation (eg, tactile fremitus, dullness to percussion, crackles) suggest community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

Risk of CAP is increased in elderly patients due to age-related impairments in innate and specific immunity.  In addition, the use of atypical antipsychotic medications (eg, quetiapine) in elderly patients is associated with a much higher risk of CAP.  Although the mechanism is unclear, it may be related to cholinergic and histamine receptor-1 inhibition, which causes oropharyngeal dryness, reduced ability to generate a food bolus, and an increased risk of subsequent aspiration.

An additional risk factor in this patient is the presence of dementia (eg, Alzheimer), which increases the risk of aspiration due to impaired ability to protect the airway and coordinate the muscles involved in swallowing.

(Choice A)  A tall, thin body habitus increases the risk of spontaneous pneumothorax due to stretching of the apical regions of the lungs.  However, body habitus is not strongly associated with an increased risk of CAP.

(Choice B)  Remote hepatic resection should not influence the risk of CAP.  Recent hepatic surgery (eg, days ago) could potentially cause pneumonia due to hematogenous dissemination from a hepatic abscess.

(Choice C)  Patients taking ACE inhibitors (eg, lisinopril) may be somewhat protected against CAP; these drugs do not increase the risk of the disorder.

Educational objective:
Atypical antipsychotic medications (eg, quetiapine) increase the risk of CAP in elderly patients.  Although the exact mechanism is unclear, it may be due to anticholinergic and antihistamine effects of the drug, which reduce the ability to form a food bolus and increase the risk of aspiration.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Community acquired pneumonia

questionList.questionText:
A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to a week of fever, chills, and cough productive of foul-smelling sputum.  He has also had night sweats, anorexia, and fatigue.  The patient has no other medical conditions and takes no medications.  He has unstable housing and often sleeps in doorways or at shelters.  The patient smokes cigarettes and drinks alcohol but does not use injection drugs.  Temperature is 39.5 C (103.1 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 120/min.  The patient appears ill and disheveled with poor dentition.  Lung auscultation reveals right-sided crackles.  Leukocyte count is 18,000/mm3, and serum sodium is 128 mEq/L.  Chest imaging findings are shown in the image below:

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Lung abscess

Pathophysiology

  • Aspiration of oropharyngeal/gingival anaerobes
  • Risk factors: dysphagia, substance use, seizures
  • Pneumonitis → pneumonia → abscess/empyema

Manifestations

  • Subacute fever, night sweats, weight loss
  • Cough with putrid sputum

Diagnosis

  • Cavitary infiltrates with air-fluid levels
  • Cultures rarely useful

Treatment

  • Ampicillin-sulbactam, imipenem, meropenem
  • Alternate: clindamycin

This patient's alcohol use, foul-smelling sputum, fever, leukocytosis, and cavitary infiltrate with air-fluid level likely indicates lung abscess.  Most cases are caused by the aspiration of oropharyngeal anaerobic bacteria (eg, Peptostreptococcus, Fusobacterium) in the setting of dysphagia or impaired consciousness (eg, due to alcohol abuse or seizures).  Those with poor dentition or gingival disease are at greatest risk.

Because anaerobic bacteria grow slowly, manifestations generally arise over 1-2 weeks.  Common symptoms include fever, night sweats, weight loss, and cough with foul-smelling sputum.  Although the mechanism is unclear, pulmonary infections (eg, pneumonia, lung abscess) and malignancies often cause mild hyponatremia due to the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).  Chest x-ray and CT scan typically reveal cavitary infiltrates, often with air-fluid levels in the superior lower lobe or posterior upper lobe (sections that are dependent with recumbency).

Anaerobic bacteria are difficult to isolate on culture.  Therefore, patients with suspicious symptoms generally receive empiric antibiotics with an agent that has good pulmonary penetration and efficacy against obligate and facultative anaerobes.  Ampicillin-sulbactam is considered first-line therapy.  Clindamycin is reserved for those with beta-lactam allergy due to high risk of subsequent Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection.  A prolonged course is indicated; surgical intervention (eg, pneumonectomy, lobectomy) may be required in the rare cases that do not improve with antibiotic therapy.

(Choice B)  Pulmonary aspergillosis is seen primarily in immunocompromised patients and presents with fever, pleuritic pain, and hemoptysis.  Imaging typically reveals a fungus ball within a cavity or nodules with surrounding ground-glass infiltrates (ie, halo sign), not consolidation with cavitation.

(Choice C)  Small cell lung cancer can cause hyponatremia due to release of antidiuretic hormone but would not cause cavitary lesions; in addition, fever, leukocytosis, and a short duration of symptoms would be uncommon.  Squamous cell carcinoma can cause cavitary lung lesions; however, air-fluid levels are uncommon and a short duration of systemic symptoms would be atypical.

(Choice D)  Aspiration of gastric contents can result in chemical pneumonitis.  Symptoms typically arise within hours (not a week) and include significant dyspnea and minimal fever.

(Choice E)  Pulmonary tuberculosis can cause fever, night sweats, and cavitary lung lesions.  However, symptoms typically occur over several weeks or months; air-fluid levels (seen in 20% of cases of pulmonary tuberculosis) are  more common with lung abscess; and marked leukocytosis and foul-smelling sputum are more suggestive of lung abscess.

Educational objective:
Lung abscess is usually due to the aspiration of oropharyngeal anaerobic bacteria.  Patients with dysphagia or episodes of impaired consciousness (eg, drug or alcohol abuse) are at high risk.  Symptoms include subacute fever, night sweats, weight loss, and cough with putrid sputum.  X-ray reveals cavitary infiltrates, often with air-fluid levels.

questionList.questionText:
A 48-year-old woman comes to the office due to progressive dyspnea for 1 month.  Five years ago, the patient underwent right lung transplantation for idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension.  She has been on stable immunosuppressive therapy.  She has never smoked cigarettes.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6F), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 16/min.  Physical examination shows clear lungs.  Chest x-ray reveals no new abnormalities.  Pulmonary function test results are as follows:

Forced vital capacity (FVC)76% of expected
Forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1)60% of expected
FEV1/FVC ratio68%

Bronchoalveolar lavage cultures grew no viral, bacterial, or fungal organisms.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Lung transplant rejection

Acute

(cell-mediated response)

Chronic

(mixed cell-mediated
& antibody response)

Clinical
presentation

  • ≤6 months after transplant
  • Asymptomatic or fever, cough, dyspnea
  • Months to years after transplant
  • Progressive cough & dyspnea
  • History of acute episodes

Diagnosis

  • BAL to rule out infection
  • Biopsy: submucosal lymphocytic infiltrate, perivascular inflammation
  • Obstructive pattern on PFT
  • BAL to rule out infection
  • Biopsy: submucosal lymphocytic infiltrate, bronchiolitis obliterans

Management

  • High-dose glucocorticoids
  • Supportive management
  • Possible repeat transplant

BAL = bronchoalveolar lavage; PFT = pulmonary function testing.

This lung transplant recipient with progressive dyspnea, an obstructive pattern (ie, FEV1/FVC <70%) on pulmonary function testing (PFT), and no evidence of infection (eg, no fever, chest x-ray abnormalities, or organisms on bronchoalveolar lavage) likely has bronchiolitis obliterans, the major manifestation of chronic lung transplant rejection.  Despite immunosuppressive therapy, nearly half of lung transplant recipients develop evidence of chronic rejection by 5 years posttransplant.

Bronchiolitis obliterans results from chronic lymphocytic inflammation of the small airway submucosa, which eventually leads to ingrowth of fibromyxoid tissue into the airway lumen.  Some small airways become partially obstructed whereas others become fully obstructed ("obliterated"), trapping air distally.  Patients commonly have gradually progressive dyspnea and nonproductive cough.  Chest x-ray is often unremarkable but can reveal evidence of air-trapping in advanced disease.  The diagnosis is usually made based on a consistent clinical presentation and an obstructive pattern on PFT.  Sometimes confirmatory histopathologic lung biopsy findings (eg, circumferential elastin rings in the airway lumen) are necessary.  Bronchoalveolar lavage helps rule out infection (eg, viral pneumonia), which can cause a similar presentation in lung transplant recipients.

(Choice B)  Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary disease can lead to pulmonary hypertension and may cause decreased diffusion capacity on PFT, but an obstructive pattern is not expected.

(Choice C)  Emphysema causes an obstructive pattern on PFT, but it is less likely than bronchiolitis obliterans in this never-smoking patient who is 5 years post–lung transplant.

(Choices D, E, and F)  Hypersensitivity pneumonitis, pulmonary edema, and pulmonary fibrosis all involve edema or fibrosis of the pulmonary interstitium with decreased compliance and a restrictive pattern on PFT.  In addition, crackles are usually present on lung auscultation with all 3 conditions.

Educational objective:
Bronchiolitis obliterans is the major manifestation of chronic lung transplant rejection and is common in lung transplant recipients >5 years posttransplant.  The diagnosis is usually made based on a consistent clinical presentation (eg, gradually progressive dyspnea and nonproductive cough) and pulmonary function testing showing an obstructive pattern.

questionList.title: Lung transplantation

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Chronic transplantation rejection.

questionList.questionText: A 56-year-old man is evaluated in the preoperative clinic 4 weeks prior to an elective right knee replacement for severe osteoarthritis.  Medical history is notable for hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.  The patient uses inhaled bronchodilators, inhaled corticosteroids, and amlodipine.  He has never required hospitalization for respiratory-related issues.  The patient is able to perform all basic activities of daily living without dyspnea and was playing golf once a week prior to the knee pain limiting his activity.  He previously smoked a pack of cigarettes daily beginning at age of 21 but has cut down to 3 or 4 cigarettes per day over the last 2 years.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Oxygen saturation is 92% on room air.  Lung auscultation shows slightly diminished breath sounds with prolonged expiration but no wheezes or crackles.  Heart sounds are normal.  The abdomen is soft and nontender with no organomegaly.  There is no extremity edema.  The right knee has crepitus and decreased range of motion.  Blood cell counts and serum chemistry studies are within normal limits.  Which of the following interventions is most appropriate to decrease the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is at increased risk for postoperative pulmonary complications, including pneumonia and respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.  Medical optimization of COPD symptoms (eg, dyspnea, wheezing) prior to surgery helps reduce this risk.  Active smoking is also an independent risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications, and this effect is amplified in patients with underlying lung disease.

Even a small amount of active smoking (eg, 3 or 4 cigarettes per day) is associated with increased postoperative pulmonary risk.  In all patients anticipating elective surgery, immediate smoking cessation is recommended as those who quit smoking >4-8 weeks prior to surgery substantially decrease their postoperative pulmonary risk.  Lesser durations of preoperative smoking cessation do not reduce the risk, likely because the airway inflammation and increased bronchial mucus production induced by smoking requires some time to improve.

(Choice B)  Long-term oxygen therapy improves mortality in patients with COPD and significant chronic hypoxemia (ie, resting arterial oxygen saturation ≤88%); however, it has not been shown to benefit patients with lesser degrees of hypoxemia.

(Choice C)  There is no evidence that preoperative antibiotics active against respiratory pathogens (eg, moxifloxacin) decrease the risk of pneumonia, COPD exacerbation, or other postoperative pulmonary complications.

(Choice D)  Systemic glucocorticoids are indicated in an acute exacerbation of COPD, but preoperative use has not been shown to decrease the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications.

(Choice E)  Theophylline is sometimes used as an additional therapy in patients with COPD who have persistent symptoms despite smoking cessation and optimal usage of inhaled bronchodilators and corticosteroids.  However, it is not indicated in this patient whose symptoms are controlled by his current therapy.

Educational objective:
Active smoking increases the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications (eg, pneumonia, respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation), especially in patients with underlying lung disease (eg, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease).  Smoking cessation is recommended >4-8 weeks prior to elective surgery as it has been shown to reduce the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Perioperative medical management

questionMappingReferencesList.title: A prospective survey of the incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications.
Impact of smoking on perioperative outcomes after major surgery.

questionList.questionText: A 32-year-old man comes to the office due to 3 days of fever, malaise, and cough productive of clear sputum.  He has had no nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, sore throat, or chest pain.  The patient has a history of mild, intermittent asthma and seasonal allergic rhinitis.  He does not use tobacco but drinks alcohol occasionally.  His 2-year-old son had fever, cough, and rhinorrhea last week.  Temperature is 38.3 C (101 F), blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min, respirations are 20/min, and pulse oximetry is 96% on room air.  The oropharynx is normal, and palpation of the neck shows no cervical lymphadenopathy.  Lung auscultation reveals crackles at the right lung base and occasional expiratory wheezing.  Heart sounds are normal.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has fever, malaise, and cough productive of clear sputum.  Although these findings are often seen in viral upper respiratory infection, most patients have concurrent upper airway symptoms (eg, rhinorrhea, coryza, sore throat).  In addition, the presence of crackles at the right lung base indicate that the alveoli in this area are collapsed by fluid or exudate.  This raises concern for pneumonia, a potentially life threatening infection that requires further evaluation with chest x-ray for diagnosis.

CAP is a pulmonary parenchymal infection that may be caused by bacterial (majority), viral (30%), or fungal pathogens.  Symptoms often develop acutely and frequently include fever, cough, pleuritic chest pain, and dyspnea.  Tachycardia, tachypnea, and pulmonary auscultation abnormalities (eg, focal crackles) may be present.  Clinical and physical findings are notoriously poor at predicting the presence of pneumonia (<50% sensitivity).  Therefore, even though patients are sometimes diagnosed clinically in practice, guidelines require a lobar, interstitial, or cavitary infiltrate on chest imaging (usually chest x-ray) for confirmation.

Patients with a pulmonary infiltrate are generally treated with empiric antibiotics because rapid differentiation between a viral and bacterial etiology is often difficult; in addition, antibiotics reduce risk of secondary bacterial pneumonia in the setting of primary viral lung infection (Choice G).  The presence of a focal infiltrate makes viral bronchitis much less likely than CAP; therefore, symptomatic treatment would not be appropriate.

(Choices A and B)  Azithromycin can be used for the outpatient treatment of CAP when local resistance rates in Streptococcus pneumoniae are <25%.  Ceftriaxone plus azithromycin is first-line for hospitalized patients (not in intensive care).  However, diagnosis with chest x-ray is required prior to treatment.

(Choice D)  Mycoplasma pneumoniae is the most common cause of atypical pneumonia (indolent fever, malaise, and cough) and frequently results in the formation of cold agglutinins (not routinely used for diagnosis).  However, M pneumoniae is less likely to cause focal findings on lung examination, can be accompanied by extrapulmonary (eg, gastrointestinal) manifestations, and usually causes indolent rather than acute symptoms.

(Choice E)  Influenza tends to cause the abrupt onset of systemic (eg, fever, malaise, myalgias) and upper respiratory (eg, rhinorrhea, sore throat) symptoms.  This patient has no upper respiratory symptoms.

(Choice F)  Sputum and blood cultures are typically not required in the outpatient setting as empiric oral antibiotics (eg, amoxicillin, levofloxacin) are usually curative.  An infiltrate on chest x-ray confirms CAP.

Educational objective:
The diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia requires the presence of a lobar, interstitial, or cavitary infiltrate on chest imaging (eg, chest x-ray).  Sputum and blood cultures are typically not required in the outpatient setting as empiric oral antibiotics are almost always curative.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Community acquired pneumonia

answerChoiceList.choice: Symptomatic treatment with follow-up in 3 days

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Testing strategies in the initial management of patients with community-acquired pneumonia.

questionList.questionText: A 26-year-old primigravida at 11 weeks gestation comes to the office due to a 3-week history of heat intolerance, excessive sweating, and palpitation.  She has no prior medical conditions, and her only medication is a daily prenatal multivitamin.  Blood pressure is 116/60 mm Hg and pulse is 102/min and regular.  Physical examination shows a diffusely enlarged, nontender thyroid.  Laboratory studies reveal normal blood cell counts, serum chemistry studies, and liver function tests.  TSH is <0.01 μU/mL, and free T4 and T3 levels exceed the trimester-specific reference range.  Thyrotropin receptor antibody assay is positive.  Propylthiouracil is begun.  At follow-up 1 month later, the patient reports improvement in her prior symptoms, but she has had a sore throat for the past 2 days.  Temperature is 38.6 C (101.5 F), blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 14/min.  The soft palate, pharynx, and tonsils are red and swollen, and there are scattered ulcerations in the posterior pharyngeal wall and soft palate.  No cervical adenopathy is present.  The lungs are clear on auscultation.  Rapid streptococcal antigen testing performed in the office is negative.  Blood samples are obtained for laboratory studies.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Drug-induced neutropenia

Common triggers

  • Methimazole, propylthiouracil
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
  • Clozapine
  • Sulfasalazine

Mechanism

  • Immune mediated: drug or metabolite binds to neutrophils & triggers a cell-mediated or humoral response
  • Bone marrow toxicity: drug or metabolite directly or indirectly damages granulocyte precursors

Manifestations

  • Usually within 3 months of drug exposure
  • Oropharyngeal ulceration ± fever
  • Other cell lines unaffected

Management

  • Discontinue inciting medication
  • Antibiotics in setting of treatable infection
  • Consider granulocyte colony-stimulating factor

This patient initially presented with Graves disease (ie, elevated thyroid hormone levels, suppressed TSH, positive assay for thyrotropin receptor antibodies).  In pregnant women, radioiodine therapy for Graves disease is contraindicated due to the risk for fetal hypothyroidism, and thyroidectomy is generally avoided due to the risk for spontaneous abortion or premature delivery.  Therefore, antithyroid medication is preferred; during the first trimester, propylthiouracil is recommended over methimazole due to a lower risk for congenital anomalies.

However, antithyroid medications are associated with an increased risk for drug-induced neutropenia (also often referred to as agranulocytosis), which commonly presents with fever, sore throat, and oral ulcerations (as seen in this patient).  Drug-induced neutropenia occurs in up to 0.5% of patients on antithyroid medications and can increase the risk for rapidly life-threatening infections.

If a patient develops symptoms of infection while taking an antithyroid drug, the drug should be immediately discontinued.  A white blood cell count, along with blood- and organ-specific (eg, throat) cultures, should be obtained.  A total WBC count <1,000/mm3 warrants initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics.  Because antithyroid drug–related neutropenia is idiosyncratic (largely immune-mediated) and not dose related, the drug should not be continued at any dose (Choice E), and alternate treatment (eg, thyroidectomy) may be required.

(Choice A)  Fevers can be a manifestation of thyroid storm, which is caused by an abrupt release of thyroid hormone and is treated with beta blockade; however, this patient lacks expected associated symptoms of neuropsychiatric symptoms (eg, delirium) and tachycardia.  Furthermore, pharyngeal ulcers are uncommon.

(Choice B)  Acute adrenal insufficiency (ie, adrenal crisis) presents with fever, severe hypotension, and gastrointestinal symptoms (eg, nausea, abdominal pain), and requires immediate administration of hydrocortisone.  This patient's pharyngeal ulcers and recent initiation of propylthiouracil are more suggestive of drug-induced neutropenia.

(Choice D)  Antinuclear antibodies are commonly used as an initial test for systemic lupus erythematosus, which can cause mucositis and painless oral ulcers.  However, the acute onset of sore throat and fever in a patient taking an antithyroid medication is more concerning for agranulocytosis, and discontinuation of propylthiouracil is necessary.

Educational objective:
Antithyroid drugs (eg, propylthiouracil, methimazole) can cause agranulocytosis, a rapidly life-threatening condition that can manifest with infection, fever, sore throat, and oral ulcerations.  If a patient taking antithyroid drugs develops symptoms of infection, the drug should be stopped immediately, white blood cell count checked, and broad-spectrum antibiotics initiated.

questionList.questionText: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to a 4-day history of fever, shortness of breath, and right-sided pleuritic chest pain.  Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypercholesterolemia.  Temperature is 38.7 C (101.7 F), blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 20/min.  Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion are noted in the right lower lung field.  Chest x-ray reveals a right lower lobe infiltrate and a pleural effusion.  Ultrasound examination reveals the pleural effusion is free flowing without loculation.  Thoracentesis is performed, and Gram stain of the fluid shows segmented neutrophils and gram-positive cocci in pairs.  Cultures of the fluid, blood, and sputum are pending.  In addition to systemic antibiotic therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questionList.explanationText:
Parapneumonic effusions

Uncomplicated

Complicated

Etiology

Sterile exudate in pleural space

Bacterial invasion of pleural space

Radiologic
appearance

Small to moderate & free flowing

Moderate to large, free flowing
or loculated

Pleural fluid characteristics

  • pH ≥7.2
  • Glucose ≥60 mg/dL
  • WBCs ≤50,000/mm3
  • LDH ≤1,000 units/L
  • pH <7.2
  • Glucose <60 mg/dL
  • WBCs >50,000/mm3
  • LDH >1,000 units/L

Pleural fluid
Gram stain & culture

Negative

Positive or negative*

Treatment

Antibiotics

Antibiotics & drainage

*Gram stain & culture are often falsely negative due to low bacterial count.  Both are typically positive in empyema, which represents advanced progression of a complicated effusion.

LDH = lactate dehydrogenase; WBC = white blood cell.

This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with community-acquired pneumonia, with chest x-ray revealing a parapneumonic effusion.  Most parapneumonic effusions are uncomplicated, resulting from increased flow of sterile exudate into the intrapleural space.  These effusions typically resolve with antibiotic therapy for pneumonia and require no additional treatment.  Complicated parapneumonic effusion (and empyemas, which represent the advanced stage of complicated parapneumonic effusions) must be recognized because they involve bacterial invasion into the pleural space.  In addition to antibiotics, drainage of the effusion via chest tube is typically required.  This patient's positive pleural fluid Gram stain showing gram-positive cocci in pairs (consistent with Streptococcus pneumoniae) is diagnostic of a complicated effusion, and chest tube placement is indicated.

Oftentimes, pleural fluid bacterial counts are low in a complicated effusion, and Gram stain and bacterial culture are falsely negative.  In such cases, additional pleural fluid studies can confirm a complicated effusion.  Because bacteria in the pleural space metabolize glucose and generate acidic waste, low pleural fluid glucose levels (eg, <60 mg/dL) or pH <7.2 is diagnostic of a complicated effusion and is an indication for drainage.  Significantly elevated leukocytes (eg, >50,000/mm3) and lactate dehydrogenase levels >1,000 U/L also suggest bacterial invasion of the pleural space and may be indications for drainage.

(Choice A)  Bronchoscopy can be helpful in the diagnosis of pneumonia with an atypical presentation (eg, chronic symptoms, unresponsive to antibiotics), but it is not indicated in this patient with a typical presentation of community-acquired pneumonia.

(Choice B)  Chest physiotherapy may help dislodge pulmonary mucus and is used in patients with cystic fibrosis, but it has not shown benefit in the management of acute pneumonia.

(Choice D)  Serial chest x-rays (to ensure resolution of the effusion) without additional therapy are appropriate for an uncomplicated parapneumonic effusion.

(Choice E)  Systemic corticosteroid therapy is used for an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, but it does not have a role in the management of parapneumonic effusions.

(Choice F)  Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) is sometimes needed to debride and remove loculated and fibrotic fluid collections that develop with an advanced complicated effusion (ie, empyema).  However, this patient's complicated effusion is free flowing and amenable to chest tube drainage.

Educational objective:
Complicated parapneumonic effusions involve bacterial invasion into the pleural space and require drainage in addition to antibiotic therapy.  Positive pleural fluid Gram stain or culture is diagnostic of a complicated effusion and is an indication for chest tube placement.

questionList.title: Parapneumonic effusion & Empyema

answerChoiceList.choice: Serial chest x-rays without additional therapy
